title: Royal Caribbean cruise captains reveal the best panoramas at sea
text:
View
comments
Few could deny that being at sea provides a breathtaking serenity and a fresh perspective on the world.
For the lucky ones working aboard a ship, they are able to unlock some of the most well-kept secrets usually reserved for nautical adventurers who spend their lives on the oceans.
Royal Caribbean has tapped into the expertise of its 23 ship captains to reveal some of the most incredible panoramas encountered while voyaging to its 260 destinations.
Scroll down for video
The mesmerising Hubbard Glacier in Alaska was highly recommended by ship captains who said that the spectacular colours vary with the light
The Hubbard Glacier, Alaska
Many of the captains surveyed cited the glaciers of Alaska as one of their favourite views for the sheer magnitude and scale of the view.
In particular the scenery from Yakutat to Disenchantment Bay stood out for captains.

Voyager of the Seas' captain Sindre Borsheim, commented: 'It is different every time you see it, as the colours vary with the light.'
Captain Juan Caranti, from Radiance of the Seas, added: 'When a piece of ice falls into the ocean it makes an extraordinary roar, like a thunderstorm.'
Sydney Harbour, Australia
One of the best ways to see the iconic Sydney Opera House and harbour is by ocean liner due to the extensive waterways

One of the best ways to witness the iconic Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge is by the ocean.
It was no wonder therefore, that this sight was listed as one of the best by captains, due to the harbour boasting more than 240 kilometres of shoreline and meandering waterways.
Captain Rick Sullivan, from Explorer of the Seas, called Sydney Harbour 'the most iconic harbour in the world.'
Venice Harbour, Italy
The architecture of Venice Harbour in Italy was said to be among the best sights in the whole world, as chosen by ship captains
Many of the captains who submitted their recommendations chose Venice's stunning architecture as one of the best liner sights.
In particular the sight of the sun rising over the buildings in the early morning sun was said to be especially breathtaking.
Geiranger Fjord, Norway
The south western Norwegian Geiranger fjord was listed in the top 12 liner sights for its snowcapped mountains and wild waterfalls
The Geiranger fjord can be found in the south western part of the county of MÃ¸re og Romsdal, in Norway.
The deep blue water is surrounded by majestic, snow-covered mountain peaks, wild waterfalls and lush, green vegetation.
Captain Espen Been, from Grandeur of the Seas, said: 'The point where the mountains meet the sea and the snow from the surrounding tops is mirrored, it seems like everything is blooming.'
Stockholm archipelago, Sweden
The multitude of tiny island, rocks and islet that form the Stockholm archipelago in Sweden are said to be particularly beautiful with the houses resembling doll houses
The archipelago through which ships sail as they come into Stockholm was described as being unique due to the thousands of rocks and tiny islands which have to be navigated on the entry to the port.
Captain Espen Been said that homes look like doll's houses as you sail past.
The area is the second largest archipelago in the Baltic Sea and consists of nearly 30,000 islands, islets and rocks - from Arholma in the north to Landsort in the south - with rugged nature blending into wooded islands, rocky cliffs and sandy beaches.
Island of Moorea, French Polynesia
The turquoise sea contrasts spectacularly with the vibrant green mountains on the incredible Island of Moorea in the French Polynesia
The beautiful green, jagged volcanic mountains of the Island of Moorea helped the French Polynesian isle finds its way into the top views for the ship captains.
What stood out for most surveyed is the juxtaposition of sandy beaches against its dramatic mountain ranges. It is also a great area for guests, with rainforest trails and scuba diving being popular activities for adventurous travellers.
Vesuvius, Naples, Italy
The sight of Mount Versuvius towering over Naples at sunrise is said to be one of the most extraordinary sights from sea
The landscape of the Mediterranean was regularly cited by the Captains as housing some of the best views in the world.
However more than one captain said that in particular the view of Vesuvius towering over Naples at sunrise is an extraordinary image.
Golfo di Poeti, La Spezia, Italy
Popular choice: Many of the captains commented that it is easy to see why Golfo di Poeti has earned such devotion
It was a favourite spot of Lord Byron and this is how that the Golfo di Poeti in La Spezia earned its name.
Many of the captains commented that it is easy to see why Golfo di Poeti has earned such devotion.
In particularly many commented that the view of the Golfo di Poeti as ships sail out of the port of La Spezia isstunning.
Nice, France
Venture out to sea to see popular tourist destinations such as Nice from an entirely new perspective
Many will recognised the sight of popular tourist destination, but captains say this is best viewed at sea.
They commented that the sight of neighbouring port of VilleFranche deserved a place in the top 20 thanks to its mountainous backdrop.
Captain Tomas Busto, from Adventure of the Seas, said: 'When the ships arrive in the Mediterranean in April, the mountains are still snow-capped but the beaches are welcoming sunbathers.'
Kotor, Montenegro
What makes the area of Kotor, Montenegro different from others is the Venetian style architecture set against the ruggest mountains behind
Captain Lis Lauritzen, from Vision of the Seas, said that Kotor in Montenegro deserved a spot on the list of favourite views due to being completely different in terms of view and environment.
What makes the area different from others is the Venetian style architecture set against a mountainous backdrop.
The port is located in the Gulf of Kotor which is considered to be one of the most indented parts of the Adriatic Sea. The historic town of Kotor has little commercial traffic and is therefore lesser known.
Vancouver, Canada
Treasured view: The sight of skyscrapers surrounded by deep, green trees is truly a breathtaking sight to behold
With rising skyscrapers and lush vegetation, it it easy to see why Canada's Vancouver was acknowledged in the survey.
Captain Rick Sullivan, from Explorer of the Seas, explained that Vancouver made the list due to the perspective of sailing under the First Narrows Bridge into Vancouver Harbour looking at the city against the backdrop of the mountains.
The English Channel, UK
A spectacular sunset awaits those heading out to sea along the English Channel
Some of the greatest sights can be seen just leaving the UK, with the English Channel recommended as one of the best views.
Captain Henrik Loft Soerensen, from Brilliance of the Seas, said: 'The expanse of English Channel is beautiful and peaceful.'
